answers.answer: If it is a burning pain below the breastbone, maybe slightly to the right, it's probably from duodenal ulcer. NSAIDs are common cause. H. pylori infection, which is common may aggravate inflammation and ulcer.Have a test for H. pylori. Ulcus is diagnosed with duodenoscopy and treated with anti-acid drugs.

question: HiI am a 47 year old obese woman with type II diabetes (insulin dependent).  I recently had an injury to my knee with a torn miniscus and this resulted in a prescription for an NSAID anti-inflammatory medication (e.g. arthrotec) and subsequent surgery to scope the cartilage.  Over the past several months I have been experiencing extremely painful hunger pains that leave me nauseated and on a few occasions having to vomit (very uncharacteristic of me to vomit).  The pains are so sharp and is only eased temporarily by eating a small container of yougurt.  I have been experiencing nocturnal eating (although not to the extremes you hear about).  Usually I will get up and grab a yogurt or non sugar popsicle (in the past I have eaten cereal in the middle of the night but have chosen to not purchase this because of my propensity to do so).  I have also gained some 50 lbs over the past year (after having lost weight due to my untreated diabetes).  NOw that I'm treated I am hungry all the time but the most disturbing problem is the painful nature of my hunger "pains".  Please help!dldlrmThis discussion is related tohttp://www.medhelp.org/posts/show/228315.
title: painful hunger
